perturbation.original_text:
Where IntriCon supplies Products to a third party, IntriCon will, at its cost:
(a) obtain and maintain all governmental and regulatory approvals necessary for it to exercise, and comply with all laws and regulations applicable to the exercise of, its license rights under this Agreement; and
(b) comply, and ensure that all Products comply, at all times with any technical standards as may reasonably be required by law, and any licensing requirements, standards, or protocols established by the Hearing Instrument Manufacturers' Software Association (HIMSA) and the Hearing Instrument Manufacturers' Patent Partnership (HIMPP), it being acknowledged that Dynamic Hearing makes no representation or warranty that the exercise of the rights granted under this Agreement will not infringe any rights held by HIMSA, HIMPP or any other third party.
perturbation.changed_text:
Where IntriCon supplies Products to a third party, IntriCon will use commercially reasonable efforts to:
(a) obtain governmental approvals necessary for it to exercise its license rights under this Agreement; and
(b) endeavor to ensure that all Products comply with technical standards and licensing requirements established by the Hearing Instrument Manufacturers' Software Association (HIMSA) and the Hearing Instrument Manufacturers' Patent Partnership (HIMPP), it being acknowledged that Dynamic Hearing makes no representation or warranty that the exercise of the rights granted under this Agreement will not infringe any rights held by HIMSA, HIMPP or any other third party.
perturbation.explanation: The changes replace 'obtain and maintain all governmental and regulatory approvals' with 'obtain governmental approvals'. This weakens IntriCon's obligation to ensure compliance with applicable laws, potentially creating a legal contradiction if specific regulatory approvals are legally mandated in Victoria, Australia, for the sale of hearing aids. The change replaces 'comply, and ensure that all Products comply, at all times with any technical standards as may reasonably be required by law' with 'endeavor to ensure that all Products comply with technical standards'. This significantly reduces the responsibility of IntriCon to ensure that all products always comply with applicable technical standards required by law, this creates a legal risk in Victoria, Australia.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 (Australia) which requires regulatory approvals for medical devices, including hearing aids.

perturbation.original_text: All amounts payable by IntriCon under this Agreement must be paid free and clear of and without any deduction or withholding for or on account of any present or future withholding tax, including any interest or penalties in relation to such tax (Withholding Taxes). If IntriCon is required to make any deduction or withholding for any Withholding Tax, then IntriCon must pay to Dynamic Hearing such additional amount to ensure that Dynamic Hearing receives such amount that would have been received by it as if no such withholding or deduction had been required.
perturbation.changed_text: All amounts payable by IntriCon under this Agreement must be paid without any deduction or withholding for or on account of any present or future withholding tax. If IntriCon is required to make any deduction or withholding for any Withholding Tax, then IntriCon will make reasonable efforts to ensure that Dynamic Hearing receives the correct amount.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the clause 'including any interest or penalties in relation to such tax (Withholding Taxes)' and 'IntriCon must pay to Dynamic Hearing such additional amount to ensure that Dynamic Hearing receives such amount that would have been received by it as if no such withholding or deduction had been required', and instead stating, 'then IntriCon will make reasonable efforts to ensure that Dynamic Hearing receives the correct amount', IntriCon is no longer legally obligated to cover the full amount of any withholding taxes, interest, or penalties imposed. This introduces a legal risk and contradiction, because in Australia, the payer (IntriCon) may be legally required to remit the full amount, including any interest or penalties, to the Australian Taxation Office, potentially leaving Dynamic Hearing with a reduced payment.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates Australian taxation laws requiring full remittance of withholding taxes, including interest and penalties.

perturbation.original_text:
IntriCon must keep accurate and complete records of orders received, Base Product Units / DSP Features/Modules Sold and returned and all other records reasonably necessary to substantiate all Royalty Payments to be made to Dynamic Hearing under this Agreement.
6.2 IntriCon must make all such records available for inspection, copying and audit by an independent auditor appointed by Dynamic Hearing (and to which IntriCon has no reasonable objection) during ordinary business hours at any time during the Term and for a period of one year following the expiration or earlier termination of this Agreement, provided that:
perturbation.changed_text:
IntriCon must keep records of orders received, Base Product Units / DSP Features/Modules Sold and all other records related to Royalty Payments to be made to Dynamic Hearing under this Agreement.
6.2 IntriCon may make such records available for inspection by an auditor appointed by Dynamic Hearing during business hours during the Term of this Agreement, provided that:
perturbation.explanation: The original clause requires 'accurate and complete records' and makes them available 'for inspection, copying and audit' for a period extending one year past the contracts end. This is reduced to 'records' and 'inspection'. The removal of 'accurate and complete' significantly reduces IntriCon's obligation to maintain thorough records, making it difficult for Dynamic Hearing to verify the accuracy of royalty payments. It is in contradiction of commercial law. The removal of 'copying and audit' limits Dynamic Hearing's ability to thoroughly verify records. The removal of one year extension also limits the ability to review past accounts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of implied duties of good faith and fair dealing under Australian contract law.
